Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 3. The Bodhisattva Sees the Five Sights

At that time, the bodhisattva Shvetaketu saw the five sights in Jambudvipa. He saw [the right] caste, country, era, ancestry, and woman. He saw the supreme caste, the Kshatriya caste, who are venerated as extremely noble. He saw the supreme country, a holy city in Maghadha. The era was one of great depression and sadness, yet the five degenerations had not yet increased very much. People lived for one hundred years. His ancestry was the Mahasammata lineage. Both his paternal and maternal lines had been without fault for seven generations.
Scene working notes: The canonical passage refers merely to the "bodhisattva" with no mention of "Svetaketu" (dam pa tog dkar po)

Sun of Faith - English: His mother had totally cast off the faults of women, and possessed all good qualities. In particular, she had gained enough merit to be able to carry a bodhisattva in her womb for ten months.  She had made offerings to the past Victors, and made prayers to become the Buddha's mother. He saw that Maya Devi fully possessed all those requisite qualities.

Then the bodhisattva spoke three times to the six classes of gods of the desire realm who dwelled in Tushita and elsewhere: “I shall descend from Tushita, become King Shuddhodana's son, and realize the essential nature. You who strive for the essential nature should take rebirth as a human in Magadha."

Sun of Faith - English:
The gods of Tushita beseached him, "Bodhisattva, you must understand: The world is now covered in sin and people are despicable. Jambudvipa is troubled by these eighteen people: the six Sophists, the Purnakashyapa, the Maskarin Goshaliputra, Sanjayavairatthiputra, Ajita Kesakambala, Kakuda Katyayana, Nigrantha Jnyatiputra; the six Followers, Brahmin Hetujaya, Brahmin Tulyotkshepa, Brahmin Ayuh, Brahmin Padmagarbha, Brahmin Lohita; and the six Trance Masters, Udraka Ramaputra, Aradakalama, Parivrajika Subhadra, Jatilakashyapa, and Rishi Arana.
We will prepare a Dharma Throne, twelve leagues high, for you here in Tushita. So it would be good to stay here and teach the Dharma!”
The Bodhisattva said, "Well then, friends, strike up the musical instruments!"
As they struck up all of the musical instruments, the Bodhisattva blew into a conch.
Inscription - English: Shvetaketu blows a conch and the gods play musical instruments

Sun of Faith - English: "Which of these instruments was the loudest?" asked the Bodhisattva.

The Bodhisattva said, “The sound of the conch overpowered the other sounds, I will overpower them. My nectar will satiate all beings. One lion defeats many animal herds. A single diamond pulverizes the other stones. The god Indra alone defeats hosts of powerful demi-gods. The sun alone dispels all manner of darkness. Those among you who seek the nectar of the teachings must take birth in one of the six cities [in the world].”
At that moment gods traveling through the heavens proclaimed, "Twelve years from now the Bodhitattva will enter his mother's womb."

At that time, five hundred solitary buddhas lived in Jambudvipa. One by one they gathered together from here and there and went to Varanasi. Thinking, "Now that the Buddha will soon appear, we no longer need to work for the benefit of beings," they passed beyond suffering in space without physical trace.
Inscription - English: Five hundred solitary buddhas miraculously pass beyond suffering
Scene working notes: The story here of the 500 Pratyeka-Buddhas does not occur in the main passage of the Vinayavastu from which the rest of this chapter seems to be drawn. It does, however match almost verbatim the brief accounts provided in the Lalitavistara (see below) and in the Kangyur dkar chag of both the Lhasa edition (TBRC #W26071: vol. 100, 109b.7-110a.1) and the dpe bsdur ma edition (TBRC #W1PD96682: vol. 107, p. 206). Although both of these editions of the Kangyur post-date Tarantha's work by over 300 years, they are based on earlier editions for which there does not seem to be text-searchable versions (i.e., Narthang). Here is the passage from the dkar chag in its entirety: "de'i tshe 'dzam bu'i gling na rang sangs rgyas lnga brgya tsam gnas pa rnams phan tshun du 'dus te wa ra Na sir byon/ da ste sangs rgyas myur du 'byon pas bdag cag gis 'gro ba'i don bya mi dgos so snyam ste phung po lhag med kyi dbyings su 'das/". [It is also worthwhile to note that references to the Buddha in Tuṣhita as the Bodhisattva Svetaketu occurs in the narrative right after this passage.]. Here is the account in the Lalitavistara: "de'i tshe yul wā ra ṇā si'i ri dwags kyi nags drang srong ltung ba na rang sangs rgyas lnga brgya 'khod pa de dag gis kyang sgra de thos nas nam mkha' la shing ta la bdun srid du gyen du 'phags nas me'i khams la snyoms par zhugs te sgron ma bzhin du yongs su mya ngan las 'das so/" (Lhasa Kangyur, vol. 48, 20a.5-20a.6)
